snippet.textDisplay:
Those mice with 20 buttons on the side are used by MOBA gamers. I'm not one myself, but I've heard that they don't need the mouse to be lightweight and instead prefer having more control by adjusting to the right weight. As for sensor, I don't really know if it's important for them. I, personally, am an FPS gamer and prefer the mouse to be as lightweight, fast and accurate as possible.
PS: I use claw grip for gaming and fingertip for normal use, which is why I prefer smaller mice. While Ergonomic with palm grip is easy to rest hands on, it slows me down by a lot, which is why I avoid large ambidextrous mice with a protruding medium curve towards the back.
snippet.textOriginal:
Those mice with 20 buttons on the side are used by MOBA gamers. I'm not one myself, but I've heard that they don't need the mouse to be lightweight and instead prefer having more control by adjusting to the right weight. As for sensor, I don't really know if it's important for them. I, personally, am an FPS gamer and prefer the mouse to be as lightweight, fast and accurate as possible.
PS: I use claw grip for gaming and fingertip for normal use, which is why I prefer smaller mice. While Ergonomic with palm grip is easy to rest hands on, it slows me down by a lot, which is why I avoid large ambidextrous mice with a protruding medium curve towards the back.

snippet.textDisplay: All of these appear to have a high curve or arch along the top.  Are there any recommendations for a more flat top mouse such as the (now almost impossible to find) Logitech G9x?  I use the fingertip grip meaning the mouse is held between thumb and ring finger (with support from pinky) and none of my palm touches the mouse.  High arch mice make this very difficult.  Also, light weight is important to prevent fingers from tiring out.
snippet.textOriginal: All of these appear to have a high curve or arch along the top.  Are there any recommendations for a more flat top mouse such as the (now almost impossible to find) Logitech G9x?  I use the fingertip grip meaning the mouse is held between thumb and ring finger (with support from pinky) and none of my palm touches the mouse.  High arch mice make this very difficult.  Also, light weight is important to prevent fingers from tiring out.

snippet.textDisplay:
Surprised these 2 didnt make it on the video.

G502 is a great all-arounder, FPS, MOBAS, Web browsing, working since it has tons of customizable extra buttons. if you mostly play FPS games it might not be your mouse since it is quite heavy, 112g. Love the infinite scroll wheel. Super confortable at holding with any type of grip. $45.99

Razer Viper Mini. Super light 60g mouse, fancy RGB lightning, optical switches (forget about the double clicking problem), palm grip not recommended for medium-large hands. Feels amazing on FPS games. $39.99
snippet.textOriginal:
Surprised these 2 didnt make it on the video.

G502 is a great all-arounder, FPS, MOBAS, Web browsing, working since it has tons of customizable extra buttons. if you mostly play FPS games it might not be your mouse since it is quite heavy, 112g. Love the infinite scroll wheel. Super confortable at holding with any type of grip. $45.99

Razer Viper Mini. Super light 60g mouse, fancy RGB lightning, optical switches (forget about the double clicking problem), palm grip not recommended for medium-large hands. Feels amazing on FPS games. $39.99

snippet.textDisplay:
The G305 has easily become my favorite mouse, but there is one major issue with it and that's the scroll wheel. Mine isn't accurate and can get stuck between steps and suddenly free itself. This is especially annoying in games where the scroll wheel is bound to jumping, such as Apex Legends and CS:GO. Other than that it's by far the best mouse in the line-up for claw/hybrid grippers. I've had the G603 and G502 and the G603 is just too big and heavy and the G502 is just too heavy.


Edit: After watching this video completely I have to say that Linus' take on gaming mice isn't what you should be listening to. For example, the G305 side buttons are really mushy compared to other mice, and a high arch like the one from the Razer Basilisk won't be comfortable for every grip type, especially not claw or hybrid grippers. If you want to see proper mouse reviews go check out Rocketjumpninja's channel.
snippet.textOriginal:
The G305 has easily become my favorite mouse, but there is one major issue with it and that's the scroll wheel. Mine isn't accurate and can get stuck between steps and suddenly free itself. This is especially annoying in games where the scroll wheel is bound to jumping, such as Apex Legends and CS:GO. Other than that it's by far the best mouse in the line-up for claw/hybrid grippers. I've had the G603 and G502 and the G603 is just too big and heavy and the G502 is just too heavy.


Edit: After watching this video completely I have to say that Linus' take on gaming mice isn't what you should be listening to. For example, the G305 side buttons are really mushy compared to other mice, and a high arch like the one from the Razer Basilisk won't be comfortable for every grip type, especially not claw or hybrid grippers. If you want to see proper mouse reviews go check out Rocketjumpninja's channel.

snippet.textDisplay: In my experience, Omron switches are suffering the same degree of overrating as CherryMX keyboard switches. Flamboyant keystroke ratings that become irrelevant far too soon because the stupid things will just start doubleclicking way before even coming close to those marketing ratings despite regular cleaning. Fortunately Logitech's no nonsense warranty kinda makes up for the ATROCIOUSLY BAD quality of these ridiculously overrated switches. I've already RMA'd my G703 twice before warranty expires. It sucks, because the sensor is great, and the mouse itself is super comfortable. Honest question: Is this video sponsored by Logitech?
snippet.textOriginal: In my experience, Omron switches are suffering the same degree of overrating as CherryMX keyboard switches. Flamboyant keystroke ratings that become irrelevant far too soon because the stupid things will just start doubleclicking way before even coming close to those marketing ratings despite regular cleaning. Fortunately Logitech's no nonsense warranty kinda makes up for the ATROCIOUSLY BAD quality of these ridiculously overrated switches. I've already RMA'd my G703 twice before warranty expires. snippet.textDisplay:
my G403 has this strange issue where, when I turn the mousewheel, the results on screen go either direction randomly can be up or down, up AND down... in short, the mousewheels behavior is totally random. so, I had to replace it, sadly, because otherwise it would be the perfect mouse for almost everything.
if someone experienced this strange behaviour and worked out a solution, PLEASE let me know!

snippet.textDisplay: I'm using the ReDragon M908 Impact after my Corsair Scimitar gave out. Months later, no regrets. My first MMO mouse was the Razer Naga and that one gave out in 2 years. snippet.textDisplay:
I have the G203, same shape as G305.
I don't like the sides. They curve slightly outward and slope inward to the bottom (sides are diagonal).
here's Rocket Jump Ninja: https://youtu.be/Y52gOAzNSAU?t=138

The MM710 has an even worse problem which makes it unusable for me.
The buttons stick out to the side, right where my ring finger rests. Completely ridiculous.
